hello this is chef john from food wishes

think about it totally makes sense right
and this year's offering is inspired by

but for now we better get to prep in and
the star of the show is escarole I have

this before for many a delicious recipe
and it's very easy to prep you're simply
gonna trim that bottom off which is
gonna release all those individual
leaves and then you're gonna take a
handful of those individual leaves and
kind of wad them up and just slice them
across like that and do kind of large
pieces you know the drill decide on the
size and stick with it so I'm gonna go
ahead and cut up two heads of escarole
and what we're gonna need to do is wash
those very carefully so I'm gonna put
them in a big bowl of cold water and I
did mine twice there's usually a lot of
sand and silt myths all right so we're
gonna give that stuff a very thorough
washing and then we're gonna blanch it
very briefly in salted water so
generously salt some water bring it to a
boil and once it comes to a boil we're

we're only gonna cook this for about two
minutes all right it's not even really

it for like five or six minutes until
it's kind of tender but I don't really
like that alright this is a dish that
gets finished under the broiler so I
don't want to cook it too far here so
just like two minutes and then we're
gonna fish it out into a bowl and then
to stop the cooking process we're gonna
go ahead and run cold water over that
alright you don't really need ice water
just cold water will do like I said
that's gonna stop the cooking and then
we'll simply let that drain on the side
until needed and it's on to the pancetta
phase so in a big skillet with a little
touch of olive oil I'm gonna go ahead
and crisp up some pancetta I'm gonna use
medium heat here pretty much throughout
a lot of people especially in utica use
prosciutto but I really do prefer the
pancetta for this I like to get this
fairly crisp to me you lose that
beautiful caramelized pork flavor and it
can get a little funky but I really do
like the pancetta here and as you can
see we're gonna cook that fairly well
and then what we're gonna do in our
pancetta or prosciutto looks like that
we're gonna add some kind of hot pepper
now I'm gonna use jalapeno because it's
winter and I can't really get those nice
summer hot long Italian peppers but
pretty much anything is gonna work here
and obviously if you want to use
something sweeter and milder like a bell

figure it out it's just peppers and I
just gave mine kind of a rustic chop
rustic being a euphemism for not
carrying what they look like and we're
gonna cook those in that hot pancetta
oil for just a couple minutes just till
they start to soften at which point
we're gonna add another mandatory
ingredient a whole bunch of chopped

to brown so I'm gonna give this let's
say a one-minute sizzle and then we're
gonna go ahead and pour in a cup of
chicken stock or broth and we're gonna
go ahead and bring that up to a simmer
and while we do I'm gonna give it a
couple pinches of black pepper and some

include adjusting the seasoning and as
soon as that mixture starts simmering we
are ready to finish the dish so to do
that we're gonna add our greens back in
but before we do I'm gonna add one bonus

beans and I'm using cooked cranberry
beans here also known as borlotti beans
I think that's what they are in Italian
so I'm going to stir those in those are
obviously already cooked and then at
that point we're gonna go ahead and dump
in our drained escarole and we'll take a

everything is kind of evenly distributed
or some might say distributed and then
right here let's go ahead and turn off

do not use panko do not use anything

the
surface and at this point we're gonna

nutritious and so easy
there's just nothing not to like about
it and yes the original Utica greens
does not have beans but since beans with

totally works and while I generally use
this as a side dish in this case with
some beautiful dried Italian sausage it
is certainly satisfying enough and
flavorful enough to be its own main
